passage_text: Instrumentation is the use of measuring instruments to monitor and control a process. It is the art and science of measurement and control of process variables within a production, laboratory, or manufacturing area.

RE: what is a 'loop' test in instrumentation and control? After the installation of certain categories of instruments for example certain types of detectors, there is normally a test caried out to ascertain their integrity, one of these is the 'loop' test.

A big benefit of the current loop is its simple wiring just the two wires. The supply voltage and measuring current are supplied over the same two wires. Zero offset of the base current (ie. 4mA) makes cable break detection simple: if the current suddenly drops to zero, you have a cable break.

Loop Powered typically means that you have a singe, two-wire, in-line sensor, (transmitter, transducer), that derives it's operating power via the two wires, and modulates the loop current based on the process to be measured. Depends on your definition of branch-off. You can have a power supply that is capable of supplying multiple loops, however, EACH sensor is supplied by ONE loop. You cannot power more than one sensor off a loop.... As JRaef put it, each loop supply is limited as to what it will supply.

The loop-powered sensor is in a remote location and gets its operating power from the source end over the single pair of wires. The sensor also controls the current in the single loop to give process information back to the source measuring equipment.
